body.div: Please enable JavaScript to best view this website.

div.p: To protect the health and safety of our community and staff, many Sutter County offices will be closed to the public starting March 20, 2020 until further notice.

div.a: Emergency Guide for Business and Industry

p.strong: Coronavirus (COVID-19) Update for the Yuba-Sutter Area

ul.li:
Â
Watch: Yuba-Sutter Call Center has taken more than 3,500 calls
Several dozen employees from Yuba County and Sutter County have been taking calls at the Yuba-Sutter COVID-19 Call Center since early March.

Â
Watch: Health Officer's April 27 Update
Yuba-Sutter Health Officer Dr. Luu discussed current case count and what residents can expect from the phasing-in re-opening of our community.

Â
Watch: Health Officer's April 24 Update
Bi-County Health Officer Dr. Luu discusses the two newest confirmed cases this week, and hopes to have increased testing in the near future.

Â
Watch: Small businesses with 300 employees receive emergency loans funded by Yuba and Sutter counties.
The Yuba-Sutter Economic Development Corporation is administering a zero interest loan program for small businesses impacted by the COVID-19 epidemic. With $500,000 contributed by Sutter and Yuba counties, 28 businesses with 301 employees, gross annual revenues of $39 million, and an annual payroll of $10 million, received emergency loan assistance. Brynda Stranix, president and chief operating officer of the Yuba-Sutter Economic Development Corporation explains the program.

Â
Watch: Health Officer's April 22 Update
Dr. Luu talks about the Governor's call to carefully resume some elective surgeries and procedures at hospitals. She expands on this topic to help our residents understand what that means.

li.br: To help us best capture the need in the agricultural sector for Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) and sanitation supplies, please fill out the following survey by Friday, April 24th.

ul.li:
Â
Watch: Planning Underway to Reopen Yuba-Sutter Region
Dr. Luu introduces various local elected officials and business leaders who join to talk about efforts underway to develop a plan to reopen businesses and other activities in the Yuba-Sutter area. A detailed plan is necessary, as the state of California will need to approve the proposed strategy.

div.h2: What To Do If You Are Sick

div.p: People with mild symptoms, who are not sick enough to be hospitalized, should self-isolate at home. These people should:

ul.li: Stay home for at least seven days from the start of symptoms, AND
Stay home at least 72 hours after fever is gone, AND
Stay home until respiratory symptoms have improved (coughing/sneezing)

div.p: People with severe symptoms of respiratory illness should call their healthcare provider immediately. Call ahead so that you can be safely evaluated to prevent exposing others. Your healthcare provider will evaluate you and determine the best course of action for your illness, including whether or not you should be tested.
To receive emergency notifications from Sutter County, please sign up with CodeRED.
